title: e-Paisa starts accepting wallet payments from Paytm, Mobikwik - timesofindia-economictimes
text:
MUMBAI: Payments service provider, Paytm , Mobikwik and Citrus haver tied up with e-Paisa, to enable easy payment option to customers to pay at retail outlets like grocery stores, restaurants and other small brick and mortar merchants through their mobile wallets. Merchants who are listed with e-Paisa - which is a multi lingual mobile based application for card and cash payments -would now be able to accept wallet payments. 
Once the customer enters an e-Paisa enabled store immediately he receives an alert indicating the offers that are available on the user's wallets in that store. Once he makes the purchase, the shopkeeper uses his e-Paisa application in his mobile phone to initiate a transaction which causes the wallet user to receive either a one-time password or a QR code depending on the wallet he is using. After the consumer approves it, the transaction gets completed.
Data from the Reserve Bank of India shows that close to 4.73 crore transactions valuing Rs 1429 crore were done through mobile wallets as on July 2015.
"Our belief is that if you want to digitize India, you have to digitize the point of sale. There are around 180 million plus wallets in India but they are mostly being used for money transfer or recharges. There's less friction with mobile wallet payments, where no money exchanges hands," said Siddharth Arora, founder and CEO, e-Paisa.
"From the merchant's perspective, real-time payment and settlement in today's digital age should be the norm, while keeping in mind the security of the consumer's money," said Jitendra Gupta, founder and managing director, Citrus Pay .
In a recently released report on the future of mobile payments systems Bank of America, Meryll Lynch said that in emerging markets (like India) while wallets started as being used for small ticket transactions like bill payments, foods etc. it has the potential to emerge as the dominant way of communication by leap-frogging some traditional avenues like credit or debit card and reducing reliance on ATMs for cash withdrawals.
